text: The rural cemetery or garden cemetery is a style of cemetery that became popular in the United States and Europe in the mid-nineteenth century. This article is a list of rural cemeteries in the United States. {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Name !! Year opened !! Location !! and played a strategic role in the Battle of Gettysburg.Hawthorne, Frederick W., Gettysburg: Stories of Men and Monuments, Hanover, Pennsylvania: The Association of Licensed Battlefield Guides, 1988, p. 107. It was the site of the dedication of the adjacent National Cemetery where Abraham Lincoln delivered the Gettysburg Address from a platform in Evergreen Cemetery |- | Greendale Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1853 || Meadville, Pennsylvania || |- | Mount Adnah Cemetery || style="text- align: center;" | 1853 || Fulton, New York || |- | Oak Hill Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1853 || Cedar Rapids, Iowa || |- | Oak Woods Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1853 || Chicago, Illinois ||The first burials at the cemetery did not occur until 1860 |- | Poughkeepsie Rural Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1853 || Poughkeepsie, New York || |- | Riverside Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1853 || Waterbury, Connecticut || |- | Walnut Grove Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1853 || Methuen, Massachusetts || |- | Woodland Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1853 || Cleveland, Ohio || |- | Woodlawn Cemetery || style="text- align: center;" | 1853 || Clinton, Massachusetts || |- | Chippiannock Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1854 || Rock Island, Illinois || |- | Hope Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1854 || Worcester, Massachusetts || |- | Oak Grove Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1854 || Gloucester, Massachusetts || |- | Oaklands Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1854 || West Chester, Pennsylvania || |- | Evergreen Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1855 || Portland, Maine || |- | Fairmount Cemetery || style="text- align: center;" | 1855 || Newark, New Jersey || |- | Mount Moriah Cemetery || style="text-align: center;" | 1855 || Philadelphia, Pennsylvania ||The cemetery closed its gates in 2011 and had no owner after the last board member died.
